The British sloop-of-war Rinaldo came up the Roads last night, and reports the Federal frigate Vermont to be lost.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 60, page 3.

div3.head: Army movements.
div3.p:
movements of the forces at Mananas in the Valley, are conducted with a can which precludes exposure.
Even those have been within the lines within the week know little of what is transpiring, prudently with hold what little in formation they have.
Particle arriving from Win for a few days past are unable to what "Stone-Wail" Jackson intend to whether he will fall back before the heavy of the advancing enemy, or whether will, as he did at Bull Run, firmly stand barrier to their advance, is a problem solved by the curious, whose anxiety triy reached its oniminating point-- are of his movements are as abundant the reputes numbers of the enemy, but ere if nothing really reliable from him.-- Sunday morning he still hold his post although the enemy was reported to be Winchester with an overpowering force.
is prudent generalship may be relied upon; it is his will to fight in the Valley, the my will receive a blow little less stunning their defeat at Manassas.

div3.head: The death of Capt. Taylor.
div3.p:
regret exceedingly to learn that Capt. James L. Taylor, C. S. Navy, has died of wounds received in the battle of Hampton Roads Capt. Taylor was a gallant and and, considering his age, one of the best in the service.
He was a son of if Wm Taylor, of Roanoke county, Va, it was in the United States Navy--having at the Naval Academy at Annapolis where he entered September 24th, 1865. the battle of Roanoke he was in com of the gun boat Yanny, and was paretic party praised there for his bravery and skill managing his ship.
He received his mortal on board the Congress, and under the of traces.
The death of this noble young will be universally regretted, and especially is mented by those who knew him and appreciated his manly, generous nature.

div3.head: Resolution of thanks.
div3.p:
Is the Senate, yesterday, a resolution was from the Bouse expressing the of the body to Captain Buchanan, of Virginia.
It passed the Senate unani and was received with a spirit only complementary to that gallant officer following is a copy:

Resolved, by the Congress of the Confederate states of America. That the thanks of Congress and are hereby cordially tendered, to . Buchanan, and all under his command, the unsurpassed gallantry as displayed the recent successful attack upon the naval of the enemy, in Hampton Roads.

div3.head: General Hill.
div3.p:
A few days ago, in the list of confirmations Brigadier Generals, by the Senate, the name of A. P. Hall was given.
This was It should have been Col. Ambrose Hill.
of the 13th Virginia regiment.
Gen Hill is a native of Culpeper county.
and a graduate of West Point.
Having reigned his commission some time before war, he offered his services to the Governor, and was sent to Parkersburg He has since been in the service of the State.

div3.head: Headq's 179th Regiment,
div3.p: General order, No. 1--The Commandants of this Regiment will assemble their respective companies on their parade grounds on Tuesday, March 11th, at o'clock P. M., and thence march them to the corner of Broad and 17th streets for battalion inspection, at 4 o'clock. They will also sum men them to appear at the same places on Wednesday Morning, the 12th March, 1862, at 10 o'clock A. M., and then march them to the corner of Broad and 17th streets; and at 11 o'clock M the regiment will be formed ass marched to Camp Lee, (the new Fail Grounds.) The men will bring with them arms as they have or may procure blankets, tin cup, knife and fork, spider or kettle, and a canteen.
div3.closer:
By order of Robt. F. Morress,
me 11--2t* Colonel Commanding.

div3.head: Headq's 19th Regiment,
div3.p:
order No.--The Captains of the 19th Regiment will summon the men in their respective commands to appear at their respective master grounds on Tuesday, the the 11th of March, at 4 o'clock P. M. for drill and inspection.
They will also summon them to appear at the same places on Wednesday Morning, the 12th of March, 1862, at 10 o' clock A. M. The Captains will march their companies to the corner of 4th and Franklin grets of 12 o'clock M. to form the regiment, the marched forthwith to Camp Lee, (the Grounds,) The men will bring them such arms as they have or may procure, a blanket, a tin cup, knife and fork, spider or kettle, and a canteen.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. Evans.
S. T. Pendleton,
ma 11--2t Adjutant.

div3.head: Headq'rs 23d Red. Va militia., March 11, 1862.
div3.p: the Commandants of Companies will muster the med under their command at their respective muster grounds, with the least possible all the arms under their control, and them for marching to the encampment at the New York Grounds, near the city of Richmond; and on Monday Morning, the 17th of this month, they will march to the said encampment
Each man will bring with him two blankets.
The Majors will see to the execution of this order in their respective battalions.
div3.closer:
By order of the Colonel
mh 2--4t* John Wickham Adj't.

div3.p: --All persons between the age of 15 and 45 are ordered to meet at the corner of 8th and Greece streets this (Wednesday) morning, at 10 o'clock, with blanket, tin cup, knife and fork, spider or brile, and a canteen Bounds, between 10th and 4th streets; and Broad and Cary streets is hoped there will be no delinquents, so to necessity of sending a squad after them lay be avoided,
div3.closer:

W. F. Atkinson, Capt.,
1st Co 1st Bat. 19th Reg't Va. Militia.

div3.head: 79th Regiment Va. Militia--6th Company, attention.
div3.p:
--The members of this company will assemble at, labrook's Warehouse, on 18th street, this (Wednesday) morning, the 12th inst., at o'clock A. M., prepared to go into camp.
I hope all the men will appear promptly, or they will have to be made to do so.
The bounds of this company are as follows: North by Broad street, west by 17th street, south by the river, and east by 20th street. mh 12--1t*

div3.head: 179th Reg't Va. Militia, attention.
div3.p: --The 5th Company will assemble the Old Market, this Morning, at 10 o'clock. The boundary of the Company is as follows: On the north by Broad street; on the east by 17th street; on the south by James river; on the west by 4th street.

By order of Col. Robt F. Morriss.

div4.p:
In this city.
February 20th by the Rev. Mr. Minnegerode, Mr. Dekaos Middleton, of South Carolina, to Miss Lemina Courtney, of this city.
In Charles City county, by the Rev, Then, Binford, on the 27th sit, Dr. Edward Epps, of New Kent co, and Miss Lizzie Bradley, youngest daughter of John W. Bradley, of Charles City county, Va,
In Some, Ga., on the 6th inst., by the Rev. Dr. Easter, of the Episcopal Church, Mr. E. W. Powell and Miss Sue G. Wharton both of this city.
On Monday night, of scarlet fever, Mary W, only daughter of P. Woodson and Mary S. Harwood, in the fourth year of her age.

The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral this morning, at 11 o'clock, from the residence of her parents, on Marshall street, between 9th and 10th, without further notice.
In Louisiana, after a short illness, Mrs. Ellen C. Morson, wife of James M. Morson, of Dover, Goochland county, Va.

div3.head: One hundred and twenty-five Dollars reward.
div3.p: --The following Negroes absconded from the Carbon Hill Mines on the 2d instant:
John — Dark brown; stout; 5 feet 10 to 11 inches in height; heavy brows; round features; 24 to 26 years of age; purchased last year from King William county.
Jim — Light brown; very likely; intelligent countenance; oval face; 5 feet 8 to 5 feet 9 inches in height; 24 to 26 years of age; can read and write; purchased last year from Bedford county.
Hal — Brown; stout built; 5 feet 7 to 5 feet 8 inches in height; 22 to 24 years of age; round features and cheerful expression; purchased from Essex county.

Philip — Black; very likely; intelligent countenance, stout, well made, except being slightly round-shouldered; 5 feet 10 to 5 feet 11 inches in height; 22 to 24 years of age; purchased last year from Henrico county.
John Fox--Black; rather light, but clean made; long face; 5 feet 8 to 5 feet 9 inches in height; 24 to 26 years of age.
Twenty-five dollars reward and reasonable expense of transportation, will be paid for the apprehension and delivery to me in Richmond of either one of them.
mh 12--ts Jno. J. Werth, Agt.

div3.head: Twenty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway in this city, two weeks ago, my boy, Allen, he is 16 years old, slender, and rather small for his age, copper colored with nearly straight hair, small, sharp features, has rather a fine, whining voice; had on when he left a black book coat, dark drab or lead, colored pantaloons, and a military cap He is no doubt passing for a free boy and may have left the city with soldiers, they under the belief that he was free; if so, and they should see this notice, I would take it as a great favor to inform me. I will pay above reward for his apprehension.
My address is Richmond, Va., (Mayo's warehouse)
mh 12--6t* Jas. L. Scoggin.

div3.head: Attention, Volunteers.
div3.p: -- seen by the following proclamation that persons who prefer to volunteer rather than be subjected to the discredit of the militias draft, can do so by coming forward sow and declaring their willingness to serve their country of their own secured:

div4.p:
The commandants of companies of volunteers, authorizes to be rallied by the Governor, which are not yet completed.
are hereby permitted to up their commands by volunteers from the of the State until the is are mustered into service.
No substitutes will be allowed.
div4.closer:
By order of the Governor.
S. Bassett French,
Aide-de-camp.

div4.p:
It will thus be seen that the alternative presented now is, whether Virginia will volunteer to defend the Southern cause, or be subjected into service be force.
As will be seen, the chutes must be mace at once.
Will not the sons of Virginia now come forward and enlist their names.--Apply at our office, in the Whig Bailolog.
div4.closer:
Marmaduke Johnson,
John W. Bransford,
A. B Guigon.

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery Company.
div3.p: --The members of our company will assemble at the Rendezvous on the Basin bank this (Wednesday) evening at 7 ½ o'clock, prepared to remain all night, and to muster into service on Thursday morning.
We have now 70 members, and invite all who are disposed to join us to enroll themselves at ones and relieve themselves from service in the militia.
Members will bear in mind that our company is raised by authority of the Secretary of war, under the Confederate States law, and therefore is not subject to militia duty.

div3.p:
--All persons residing in the city of Richmond, west of 10th street, and who have furnished Substitutes for the War, will furnish to Col. Evans, at his office, in Belvin's Block, No. 1, this Morning, between the hours of 9 and 11 o'clock, the evidence that such Substitutes have been furnished and mustered into service for the war, in order to have their names stricken from the militia rolls.
The names of none will be stricken from the rolls except those who produce the evidence that their Substitutes have been mustered into the service for the war.

div3.head: Richmond Sayette Artillery
div3.p:
--Having re-organized and re-enlisted for two years, is desirous of receiving forty additional recruits, to raise the company to the number of one hundred and fifty.
The battery is composed of four brass six-pounders and two rifle guns, and is among the finest in the Confederate Army.
The Fayette Artillery is one of the best equipped companies in the service.
A liberal bounty will be given to each recruit.
Only men of respectability, courage, and patriotism, are, however, required.
For further particulars, apply to Peyton Johns on, 115 Main street, Richmond, or to the undersigned, at Yorktown.
div3.closer:
M C Macon,
mh 12--6t Capt. R. F. A.

div3.head: Naval medical board of examination.
div3.p: --A Board of Naval Surgeons will convene in this city on the 17th inst., by order of the Navy Department, for the examination of candidates for admission in the naval service of the Confederate States as assistant surgeons during the war.
The age of the candidate must not be less than twenty-one nor more than thirty years.
div3.closer: James Corntick, President. mh 12--2w

div3.p:
The board assembled in Richmond, Va., on the 27th February, will continue its session for a month.
Candidates presenting themselves, are required not to be lest than 21 nor over 30 years of age, and must deposit testimonials of good moral character at the office of the Secretary of Navy.

W. A. U. Spotswood,

div3.head:
By the Governor of Virginia.
a Proclamation.
supplemental to the Proclamation 10 inst.
div3.p: Applications having been made by persons in militia companies who are embraced in the proclamation of the 10th instant, to volunteer for service in companies now in the field to fill up the same; and it appearing to the Extortive that the object of the President in calling for this force will be as speedily and effectually accomplished by permitting such change of service as by the mode heretofore prescribed: Therefore, I, John Lecoper Governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia, do hereby authorizes and require the following supplemental regulations to be carried out by the officers in command of militia companies or detachments:

Any person enrolled in any militia company, who shall designate to the officer in command the company now in service to which he is willing to be assigned and shall sign a written obligation to be mustered into service in such company for the war, shall be allowed so to do.

If the company selected in at the rendezvous to which the militia company is required to assemble, he shall he taken in charge of the officer commanding such company to that rendezvous, and be reported to the officer of the company selected.
If at any other place of rendezvous, he shall be forth with ordered to that point, and before he shall obtain a discharge from the militia company, he shall obtain transportation to he point designated, and produce the certificate there of to his said officer.

If, when he reports to the officer whose company he selects to be mustered in, the maximum number required for such company shall have been made up, he shall be assigned by the General in command to some other company not completed.

Captains of militia companies or commandants of detachments who allow a such changes of service, shall forth with make cut a list of the men to whom the change has been allowed, and the company and place of rendezvous to which they are ordered, and return the same forth with to the Adjutant General, together with the obligation signed by each man, herein before required.

Given under my hard as Governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia, at Richmond, this 11th day of March, 1862, and in the eighty-sixth year of the Commonwealth.
John Letcher.
By the Governor:
Secretary of the Commonwealth

All the country papers will publish daily for one week.
mh 12--lw

Enact to declare the powers of Boards of Exemption, and to impose penalties on members of such Boards for usurping powers not conferred on them; and to amend the 6th section of an act passed February 18th, 1862, entitled "An Act amending and re- enacting the 2d section of chapter 23, of the Code of Virginia, respecting persons exempt from all military duties, and providing the mode of exemption," Passed March 11, 1864.

Be it enacted, by the General Assembly, That the true meaning of the act p ed February 13, 1862, entitled an act amending and re-enacting the 2d section of chapter 22d of the Code of Virginia, respecting persons exempt from all military duties, and providing the mede of exemptions so far as the powers conferred upon Boards of Exemption are concerned, is that said Boards of Exemption shall have jurisdiction of the causes of exemption specially set forth in said act, and of no others, and shall pass on no case of exemption until the person claiming exemption has been drafted for actual service.

That, in every case where a discharge is granted by a board of exemptions, the cause of exemption shall be entered of record, and the vote shall be recorded by yeas and nays.
and if any such board shall harp powers not conferred by said act, and shall grant a discharge from military service to any drafted person for a cause of which such board has not jurisdiction specially conferred by said act, such discharge shall be void, and each member of such board voting for such discharge and exemption, or who shall fall to perform any duty hereby imposed, shall, for every such offence, be guilty of a misdemeanor cognizable only in the circuit Court of the county or city wherein such members reside, and shall be punishable by a fine not less than one hundred, nor more than one thousand dollars, and by imprisonment at the discretion of the courts, in the county jail, for a period of not less than one month, nor more than twelve months
In all cases where substitutes have been actually placed in service, and certificates obtained, the board shall decide on the validity of the same.

The 6th section of an act passed 18th of February, 1862, entitled "an act amending and re-enacting the 2d section of chapter 22d of the Code of Virginia, respecting persons exempt from all military duties, and providing the mode of exemption," be amended and re-enacted so as to read as follows: "Every claim for exemption, or excuse, shall be filed with the clerk of the board, who shall issue process for such witnesses as the claimant or enrolling officer may require, and within five days after the draft is made, and on a day to be designated by the board the trial of cases of exemption and excuse shall commence; and the same shall be disposed of in a summary manner as speedily as may be. The clerk of the board shall promptly report to the Adjutant General the name of each person exempted or excused by the board, and the cause of such exemption in each case"
This act shall be in force from its passage.
A copy from the Rolls — Teste:
Wm F. Gordon, Jr.,
C. H. D. and K. of R.

Resolved, by the General Assembly, That the act entitled "An act amending and reenacting the second section of chapter 22 of the Code of Virginia, respecting persons exempt from all military duties, and providing the mode of exemption," passed 18th February, 1862, was not intended, and does not exempt, from such duty any deputy or sheriff of any county, or of a Sergeant of any corporation, or of the Clerk of any Court, or the deputy of any other officer
A copy from the Rolls — Teste:
Wm. F. Gorgun, Jr,
mh 12--3t C H. D and K. of R.

div3.head:
Adjr.
And Insp'r General's Officer,
div3.p: General Orders, No. 11--
I. The following Proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:

div3.head: Proclamation.
div3.p: By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in e les threatened with invasion--

I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that Martial law is hereby extended over the city of Petersburg and the adjoining and surrounding country to the distance of ten mile, and do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that of the Mayor of the city, and that enabling the Courts to take cognizance of the pronate or of wills, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, the qualifications of guardians, to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to assess county levies, and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus within the said city and surrounding country to the distance aforesaid.
In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal, on the eighth day of March, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two
(Signed,) Jefferson Davis

II, William Pannill is appointed Provost Marshal, and is charged with the due execution of the foregoing Proclamation, and will forthwith establish an efficient military police, and will enforce the following orders:

p.q:
"All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited, and the distilleries will forthwith be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed."

div3.p:
III.
All persons infringing the above prohibition will suffer such punishment is shall be ordered by the sentence of a Court-Martial, provided that no sentence to hard is bor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a Regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th Article of War.
By command of the Secretary of War
(Signed,) S. Cooper,

mh 11--1w Adjt.
and Insp'r Gen.

div3.head:
By the Governor of Virginia.
a Proclamation.
div3.p:
the President of the Confederate States has called for forty thousand additional troops from Virginia.--This call affirms that the exigencies of the public service require, in order to repel the invasion of Virginia, that her zone be called out in her defence more speedily than can be done under the operation of the law recently charted by her Legislature," No call like this has ever yet been made upon this State in vain.
Every nerve must be strung.
Every son of Virginia must respond with an ardent zeal to defend the Common wealth.
Those subject to military duty are alone required to perform this service, but gallant volunteers, who come with the will to do or die for this great cause, will be given a place in our ranks.
This war has attained a point which requires brave men and true patriots to leave their homes and grapple.
sternly with the foe. We will not tamely submit to degradation or slavery.
We will have Virginia independent and all our liberties maintained, or perish in the attempt to secure them.

Therefore, I, John Lytcher, Governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia, by virtues of authority vested in me by the. Constitution and laws, do hereby requires the militia and the volunteers of the respective counties and cities named in the schedule hereto annexed, to repair forth with to the respective places assigned them, without waiting for further orders.
Move at once to the places designated.

Commandants of regiments and companies will immediately cause their commands to be summoned, employing expresses where necessary, and when assembled, order them with expedition to the nearest railroad line, and thence to the rendezvous and report to the General in command.
Regiments will there be consolidated and formed into ten companies to a regiment, with one hundred men to each company.

Field and company officers sufficient for the force that may be assembled, will be assigned according to rank, and junior officers who have no commands will be considered supernumerary, and be returned to the ranks.
Officers in command of detachments en route to places of rendezvous will cause the necessary supplies for their commands to be furnished, giving to the persons furnishing them certificates of indebtedness, which will be paid by the Auditing Board at Richmond.

Every private having a serviceable fire-arm of any description in his possession, or who can procure one from a neighbor not able to perform duty, will carry it with him. If lost, the arms will be paid for by the State.--Those who have no arms will be provided with them at the respective rendezvous.

The loyal citizens of the West and Northwest, in counties not herein named, are earnestly invoked to form guerilla companies, and strike, when least expected, once more for the State that gave them birth.
With stern resolve and manly courage uphold the flag and the untarnished fame of the Old Dominion.
Scorn the misrule of traitors, who, with usurped authority, are desecrating our soll with a pollution worse than that of the direst enemy, and execute vengeance upon the foe who acknowledges and sustains their treason.
Given under my hand as Governor, and under the Seal of the Commonwealth of Virginia, this tenth day of March, 1862, and in the 86th year of the Commonwealth.
div3.closer:
John Letcher.
By the Governor:
George W. Mulford,
Sec'y of the Commonwealth.

div3.head: Places of Rendezvous.
div3.p: To report to Major-General T. J. Jackson at Winchester:
The forces from the counties of Morgan, Berkeley, Jefferson, Frederick, Clarke, Hampshire, Warren, Shenandoah, Hardy, Page, Rockingham, Augusta, Bath, Rockbridge, Allegheny, Botetort, and Craig.
To report to Gen. Joseph E. Johnston, at Manassas:

The forces from the counties of Fairfax, Loudoun, Prince William, Fauquier, Rappahannock, Culpeper, Madison, Greene, Orange, Albemarle, Amherst, Nelson, Campbell, Bedford, Roanoke, Pulaski.
Montgomery, Carroll, Floyd, Grayson, and the city of Lynchburg.
To report to General T. H. Holmes, at Fredericksburg:

The forces from the counties of Stafford, Spotsylvania, Caroline, King George, Westmoreland, Northumberland, Richmond, Lancaster, Essex, Middlesex, Louise, Fluvanna, Goochland, Hanover, and the town of Fredericksburg.
To report to Gen. Benj. Huger, at the city of Norfolk:

The forces from the counties of Patrick, Henry, Franklin, Pittsylvania, Halifax, Mecklenburg, Brunswick, Lunenburg, Charlotte, Prince Edward, Appomattox, Nottoway, Amelia, Cumberland, Buckingham, Powhatan, Chesterfield, Dinwiddie, Greenville, Sussex, Southampton, Surry, lsle of Wight, Nansemond, Norfolk, Princess Anne, Prince George, and the city of Petersburg.
To report to Gen. J. B. Magruder, at Williamsburg: The forces from the counties of Charles City, New Kent, James City, King William, King and Queen, Gloucester, Mathews, Elizabeth City, and Warwick.
The Militia of the following counties will not report at present, but will hold themselves in readiness to obey orders when issued by Gen. H. Heth, or Gen. H. Marshall:
The counties of Giles, Monroe, Greenbrier, Mercer, Tazewell, McDowell, Smythe, Wythe, Wyoming, Washington, Russell, Wise, Buchanan, Scott, and Lee.
To rendezvous at Monterey, in Highland county, and to report their presence there, for orders, to General Edward Johnson, who is at Camp Allegheny, Highland county:
The forces of the counties of Highland, Pendleton, and Pocahontas.
To rendezvous at the New Fair Ground, near Richmond, and to report to General Winder:
The forces of the county of Henrico, and the city of Richmond.

The Enquirer, Whig and Dispatch, publish daily for one week, and all the country papers in the State will publish this proclamation three times.
mh 10--1w

div3.head: Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
div3.p: General Orders No. 4.--

list.item:
I. The proprietors of hotels and boardinghouses will forth with report to the Provost Marshal the names of all guests at their houses, and the names of all white persons in their employment.
A list of arrivals will also be furnished to the Provost Marshal twice every day, at the hours of 10 A. M. and 8 P. M.

II.
Livery stable keepers, and owners of hacks and other public vehicles, will report to the Provost Marshal the location of their stables and the number of their horses, hacks, &c. They will also make daily reports of persons from the surrounding country putting horses or carriages in their stables.

III.
No person is permitted to pass beyond the corporate limits of the city in a back or other vehicle, or on horseback, without a passport.
Drivers of stage-coaches are specially forbidden from taking passengers at any point within the ten miles of country under martial law, either to transport them into the city or to distant places, unless such persons have passports.
By order of Brigadier General John H. Winder, Commanding, &c.

div3.closer: mh 8--1w L. R. Page, A. A. Gen'l.

div3.head: Headq'rs Dept. Of Henrico,
div3.p: General Orders, No.5.--I. Colonel John C. Porter is appointed Provost Marshal of the city of Richmond, and Capts. A. O. Godwin and J. C. Maynard are appointed Assistant Provost Marshals.

list.item: I. All communications, verbal or written, concerning passports or the location guards, must be made to the Provost Marshal.

II.
The city of Richmond is divided into two military districts, by a line commencing at Mayo's Bridge and running up 14th to Main street, thence up Main to Governor or 13th street to 12th street, thence up 12th street to the limits of the city.
The district cast of said line of division is under command of Capt. A. C. Godwin, and the district west of said line is under the command of Capt. J. C.Maynard.

III.
Samuel Maccubbin is appointed Chief of Police.

div3.closer:
By order of Brig. Gen, John H. Winder.
mh 8--5t L. R. Page, A. A. G.

div3.head: Adj't and Inspector General's Office,
div3.p: General Orders, No. 10.

General Orders, No. 9, issued March 1st, 1862, proclaiming the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, with the exception of that of the Mayor of the city of Richmond.
within the city and the surrounding country to the distance of ten miles, is hereby so modified as to permit the Courts to take cognizance of the probate of wills, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, and the qualification of guardians to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to assess county levies, and order the payment of county dues.
By command of the Secretary of War

closer.signed:
(Signed,) S. Coscob,
mh 8--1w Adj't and Inspector Gen'l

div3.head:
Confederate States of America,
Quartermaster's Office.
div3.p: to Railroads — To facilitate the transfer of Recruits from Recruiting stations to their Regiments, officers of railroad companies are notified that the Recruiting Officers are authorize to give orders of transportations for their recruits, and such orders or certificates of transportation given by the person in charge of the recruits, will be so-knowledge as sufficient vouchers for payment.

div3.head: Light Artillery Company.
div3.p: -- We invite attention to our scheme for raising a Light Artillery company, for three years or the war, to consist of six guns and 150 men. Already upward is of fifty-five good and reliable members are enrolled, and we hope to complete our organization in a few days.
Uniforms of the best quality furnished, and the men put in the field free of expense.
Bounty of $50 paid when the men are mustered in.
Traveling expenses of recruits from other cities, or the country, to this city, will be paid by us.

This company is raised by authority from the Secretary of War, who has promised to furnish us the guns as soon as the company is ready, and we think presents a fine opportunity to those who wish to enter the artillery service and relieve themselves of draft.

Recruits who have already joined, as well as those hereafter connecting themselves with the company, will report at the rendezvous, on the Basin Bank, next door to Orensha Co.'s, on Wednesday, 12th inst., for the purpose of mustering in on Thursday, 13th inst.
div3.closer:
Wm G. Crenshaw,
James Ellett.
Chas. L. Hobson,
mh 11--3t and. B. Johnston.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs of the forcer South of
Chappawansic, Camp Clipton,
div3.p:
Special order, No. 1.--In obedience to orders from Headquarters, and for other good and sufficient reasons, not only the members of the 47th Virginia Regiment, but all the members of this command of whatever arm, now absent, (except those on recruiting service) will forthwith return to their respective companies.
Those whose furloughs are not out, will be allowed to complete them when the public service admits of it, which is not the case at present.
div3.closer:
By order of Col G. W. Richardson.
Commd'g Force South of Chappawansic, Ro. W.
Eubank, A. A. A. G. mh 11--2t

div3.p: Having received authority from the Secretary of War to raise an independent battalion of Light Infantry, to be used exclusively as skirmishers and scouts, and to be attached to no ether corps, except at the discretion of the Commander-in-Chief of the department in which we may be stationed, in times of great emergency, I call for volunteers from my own and other States-- men now in service, or who have not yet enlisted — to come forward at this critical juncture, when the primal glory of our arms is partially eclipsed in a temporary gloom, and enroll their names in a corps which will come frequently in contact with the polluters of our soil and the desolator of our homes.

I propose to facilitate the organization of the battalion by offering Captaincies to those enlisting not less than thirty men, 1st Lieutenancies to those enlisting twenty-five, 2nd do. 10 those enlisting twenty.
Seventy privates will be the minimum for a company.
The usual bounty will, of course, be paid, and subsistence and transportation furnished.
For particulars, address the at Yorktown, or W. H. Scott, Druggist, Richmond, Va.
Chas. H. Causey,
mh 11--2w* Lieut. Cavalry, C. S. A.

div3.head: Attention.
div3.p:
--The organization of our company is now nearly completed.
We have the guns secured and all equipments ready as soon as we are mustered into service.
Those who do not immediately volunteer will be obliged to go into the militia service.
The system of substitution has been abandoned by the Government, so that all who are bound for service must now represent themselves in person.
This we announce upon authority.
We then earnestly invoke those who are willing to share with us the fortunes of this war, who would rather appear voluntarily upon the field in defence of their country than be the reluctant soldiers of coercion, to come forward now, this day, and enlist their names as volunteers in a great and glorious cause.
Apply at our office in the Whig Budding.
div3.closer:
Marmaduke Johnson,
John W. Bransford,
A. B. Guigon,
mh 11--ts V. J. Clutter.

div3.head: Attention.
div3.p: --The Governor's Proclamation of this date renders it necessary that the members of this command assemble at the rendezvous, in the city of Richmond, without delay.

This is, therefore, to require each and every man enlisted in this company to report for duty immediately.
On arriving in the city report at the store of Darracott, Harris & Co., No. 112 Main st. All the members must appear by Saturday, 16th inst., at the latest.
It is advised that each man bring with him at least one thick, warm blanket, and an adequate supply of suitable under-clothing.
Prompt attention to this order is enjoined on all.

div3.head: Special Notices.
div3.p:
--The Infantry Company organized at the office of Dr. Parker, in the Law Building, having received assurance of a "Battery of Light Artillery," it was unanimously resolved, at a meeting held last Saturday night, to adopt that arm of the service.
The guns will be ready in less thirty days. So soon as the company is fully organized it will go into the Camp of Instruction at the Fair Grounds.
All those disposed to join will report as early as possible, at Dr. Parker's office, as the company expects to be mustered in this week.
Meetings held regularly on Wednesday and Saturday nights.
mh 11--ts

div3.head: Light Artillery Battalion.
div3.p:
--On account of recent enactments by the Legislature, I have had to give up two of the companies I accepted for my Battalion.
I now wish two more companies--one from Virginia, the other from without the State.
Capt. S. T. Martin and Lieuts. Holliday and Garnett are recruiting a company for this command in this city.
Their office is Bank st. 2d door above 12th.

No companies need offer that will not be able to report within a short time.
The guns, I have been assured I shall receive in a short time.
mh 11--5t* Francis J. Boggs.

div3.head: Headq's 9th Reg't Va. Cavalry,
div3.p: all absentees from this Regiment will rejoin their respective companies at once.
div3.closer: J. E. Johnson, mh 11--3t* 1Col. Comd 2.

div3.head: Executives Department,
div3.p:
all Sheriffs.
and others collecting State Arma are desired to have the same boxed, marked "Col. C. Dimmock, Richmond, Va," and forwarded as soon as possible.
The compensation for collecting, and the necessary expenses of transportation to this city, will be paid on the presentation of the receipts of Col. Dimmock.. Approved,
div3.closer: John Letcher. City papers copy. mh 7--1m

div3.head: Adj't and Insp'r Gen.'s Office; [Extract]
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 51:
the regulations concerning Substitutes in the Army, dated October. 20, 1861, are hereby revoked.
By command of the Secretary of War.
div3.closer: Jno. Withers, mh 6--5t Ass't Adj't Gen'l.

div3.head:
Rally!
rally !! rally!!!--
div3.p:
Recruits wanted for the oldest Regiment of Volunteers in the C. S. Army. !--Company B, of the 1st Virginia Regiment, having re-enlisted for the war, a number of recruits are desired to fill up its ranks to the full extent of the law. Fifty recruits will be at once received on application to the undersigned.-- Fifty Dollars bounty will be paid immediately on enlisting, and subsistence and transportation will also be furnished.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Lieut. W. W. Harrison,
Recruiting Officer, At No. 3 Tenth st., bet. Main and Gary. mh8 — 6t

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillerymen.
div3.p: --All who wish to join the Henrico Light Artillery, which is fully equipped and in service on the Peninsula, will call at the Clerk's Office of Henrico Circuit Court, in the basement of the State Court House, where they can get information in regard to the bounty of $50, &c. J. H. Sands,
mh 6--12t* Capt. Comd'g.

div3.head: Virginia Rangers.
div3.p:
--Persons wishing to join a Cavalry Corps, in which the hours off duty may be spent in agreeable companionship, are invited to enlist in this one. Twenty recruits will be received if immediate application be made at No. 39, Powhatan House, or at Camp Mercer, Fredericksburg.
None but men of unexceptionable character and habits need apply.
mh 8--1w* B. B. Douglas, Capt.

div3.head:
Attention!
Marylanders.
div3.p: Persons wishing to join the Maryland Cavalry will call at the office, corner Pearl and Main sts.
div3.closer: Lieut. R. Brown, mh 6--6t* Recruiting Officer.

div3.head: Headquarters,
div3.p:
Special order No. 85.--All furloughs granted to members of Col. Richardson's regiment (47th Virginia) are here by revoked, and they are required to join their respective companies immediately.
Those detailed on recruiting service are exempt from the above order.
div3.closer: By order of Gen. Frenon: F. H. Reynolds, fe 24--12t Assistant Adj't General.

div3.p:
I Am authorized by the Secretary of War to raise an Infantry Company, and as no more new companies will be accepted until Virginia's quota has been furnished.
(this company will be counted as a part of it,) this is one of the few last chances to escape the draft; and who would be drafted?
Men accepted from all parts of the State or Confederacy.
Twelve months men can reenlist with me, 50 bounty paid as soon as inspected.
Recruiting office at the office of the Insurance Company of the State of Virginia, nuder the American Hotel, Richmond, Va. Address me,
mh 10--ts W. B. Rorims,

div3.head: Headquarters Department of Henefoo

list.item: General Orders, No. 3.--I. By virtue of authority conferred by General Orders, No. 6, Adjutant and Inspector General's Office, March 1st, 1862, Captain A. C. Godwin is appointed Provost Marshal of the city of Richmond and the adjoining and surrounding country for the distance of ten miles.
II.The Passport Office is continued at its present location, under the charge of the Provost Marshal.

III.The distillation and distribution of vinous, spirituous, and mail liquors, or other intoxicating beverage, is absolutely prohibited.
This order will be strictly enforced by the Provost Marshal against all persons found distilling, selling, giving away.
or in any manner disposing of such beverages.

IV.
All persons, of every degree, except those in the service of the State or Confederate States, having arms in their possession will deliver the same to the Ordnance Department on or before the 5th of March, 1862; otherwise they will be seized and taken possession of by the Provost Marshal.
Arms belonging to the State of Virginia will be delivered to Colonel Dimmock, at the State Arsenal, in this city.
The word arms embraces in its meaning swords, bayonets, rifles, double-barrel shot guns, and pistols of such size as may be useful in the field.
Compensation will be made for private arms delivered up or taken for public use, and Government arms, not in the public service, will be receipted for. By order of Brig-Gen. Jno. H. Winder, Commanding, &c.:

div3.closer: L. R. Page, mh 5--1yy Ass't Adj't. General.

div3.head: Stuart Horse Artillery.
div3.p:
Wanted--one hundred men, for the above splendid Battery of eight pieces — Blakely Guns and Howitzers — to act as Horse Artillery, every cannoneer mounted; with Gen. Stuart's Cavalry Brigade, Army of Potomac.
I am acting under the following orders:

div4.p:
"Capt. Jno. Esten Cooke, Volunteer Aid to Brig. Gen. Stuart, is hereby ordered to proceed to Richmond, on recruiting service for the Stuart Horse Artillery.
He will be governed by the rules and regulations for recruiting of the and I. General's Dept.C. S. A.
div4.closer: "By command of Gen Stuart." "W. E. Towles, A. A. A. Gen'l"

div4.p:
This will be the finest battery in the service.
It will be commanded by an experienced artillerist,. a graduate of West Point.
Every cannoneer is mounted, with horse and accoutrements furnished by the Government.
The company, whish is nearly made up, will be increased to 150 men, and as soon as the legal number is obtain there will be an election of officers, and the battery will take the field.

The ordinary bounty of $50 paid.
All persons wishing to join this company are requested to address me by letter, at Richmond, or apply at the Recruiting Office, opposite Goddin's Hall, 11th street, to me or to Robert D. Ward, Esq., who is associated with me.

div3.p: Having been authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Battalion or a Regiment of Heavy Artillery, for three years or the war, I should be glad to confer with Captains who have companies not yet mustered into the service, and also those who desire to raise companies.

Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are sworn into service and accepted, upon inspection, by a medical officer, together with transportation and subsistence, from the time and place of enlistment, until inspected and mustered.

Twelve months men can re-enlist, singly or by companies.
for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty.
To those citizens who have not reported themselves, as required, and who will in a few days be drafted, now is the time, and the last, to serve as volunteers.
Volunteers will be received singly or by companies, from any portion of the Confederacy.
Office under the St. Charles Hotel, Old Dominion Insurance, Company, Main street. City Post- Office, Box 877.
div3.closer: Robert F. Morriss, Colonel 179th Regiment. I have the promise of Armstrong field pieces; and should it be realized, this regiment will enter the field as Light Artillery. mh 6--12t*

div3.head: Adjutant General's Office,
div3.p: all persons subject to military duty, and who have furnished substitutes, are hereby notified that, to entitle them to the benefit of a discharge, they must furnish proof at this office that the substitute has been actually mustered into service.
Captains of companies receiving substitutes will return the Governor's certificate of exemption until the substitute is mustered in.
div3.closer: By command. Wm. Richardson, mh 10--3t Adjutant General.

div3.head: Headqrs Elliott Grays.
div3.p:
this well-known company having determined to remain in the service, is desirous of increasing the number of enlisted men to 125.
A Recruiting Office has been opened for that purpose at the store of Louis J. Bossieux 80 Main street, and also at the store of Joseph Butler, town of Manchester.
All young men who are disposed to volunteer can learn the particulars of the condition and organization of the company from Lieut. Henry Fitzgerald, who can be found at either place of rendezvous.
Recruits are entitled to pay, transportation, and subsistence, from the time and place of enrollment, and also to the bounty of fifty dollars.

I hope that this call may meet with a speedy response, and that I may never be a witness to the drafting of young men from the districts in the neighborhood of Richmond.
All recruits are to be persons of good character, and men in whom I can place implicit confidence.
div3.closer: Louis F. Bossieux, Captain Elliott Grays. Henry Fitzgerald, Lieut. Recruiting Officer. mh 10--ts

div3.head: Particular notice.
div3.p: Look out for Deserters.
The following men having deserted from my company, namely:
I will pay the amounts set opposite to each man's name, in cash, immediately on delivery at my rendezvous, on 10th street, next door to Crawford's Saloon.
div3.closer: Wm. J. Dabney, mh 10--3t* Capt. Comd'g.

div3.head: Attention Company "B," is Regiment Virginia Volunteers
div3.p: --The members of Capt. Randolph Harrison's Company. ("B,") 1st Regiment Virginia Volunteers, now in Richmond or its vicinity, whether on furlough or detailed, will meet at the store of Messrs. Yancey & Harrison at 11 A. M., on the 12th day (Wednesday) of this present month, to consult on matters of importance to the company.
Lieut. W. Wirt Harrison will be present, and explain the object of the meeting.
[Signed,]
div3.closer: Logan S. Robins, 1st Serg't, Benj. M. Crow, 3rd Serg't. mh 10--3t*

div3.head: Special notice
div3.p:
--Having enlisted men enough to muster the company into service, this is to notify those who reside in the counties of Henrico, Hanover, Louisa, Orange, Culpeper, and else where away from the city, to report at a day's notice at the rendezvous to be appointed in this city.
Blankets are scarce, and, when found, costly; and each man is advised to bring with him one thick, warm blanket; also, an adequate supply of under clothing.
A further notification will be given in a few days.
div3.closer:
N. A. Sturdivant,
T. M. Hewitt,
Wm. H. Weisiger,
Chas. R. Darracott We can still accept some forty young men who wish to enter the Artillery service. mh 10--6t*

div3.head: Recruits Richmond sharp shooters.
div3.p:
Fifty Recruits are wanted to fill up the ranks of this well-known company to the maximum number.
A bounty of $50 will be paid each recruit, and sustenance commuted until they join the company; pay commences from date officer enlistment.
None but good men need apply, as the company heretofore has sustained an enviable reputation.

This company is armed with good Hifies, and has seen as much active service as any company in the army.
Application to be made to the undersigned at Star Exchange, Bank street, or to Corporal W. J. Winfield.
div3.closer: E. E. Ds Priest, mh 3--1m* Lieut. and Recruiting Officer.

div3.head: Attention!
div3.p:
The undersigned propose to raise a company of Light Artillery to be enlisted for the war. We are happy now to announce that we have procured the guns, which will be ready for us, together with all equipments, as soon as our company is mustered into service.
To those who would like to go along with us and share with us the fortunes of this war, we earnestly appeal to come forward now and join us at office.
Besides the bounty of $50, uniforms board and lodgings will be furnished free.
Application may be made at our Recruiting office on Main, between 7th and 8th streets, or at the store of Johnston & Bransford.
div3.closer:
Marmaduke Johnson,
John W. Bransford, te 90--ts A. D. Guigon.

div3.head: Notice
div3.p:
--The Second Company of Richmond Howitzers has been reorganized, and Lieutenant David Watson elected Captain.
We are Anxious to increase the number of our Company to 120.
An opportunity is thus offered to young men of good moral character to join an old organization, which has two rifles and two howitzers, and is thoroughly equipped for field service.

Apply to B. B. Pleasants or Henry S. Jones, at Hughes, Caldwell & Co.'s, No7, Pearl street; or Wm. N. Wellford, Jr Brandy Station, Culpeper county, Virginia, or Geo. L. Christian, Charles City C. H., Virginia.
mh 10--14t*

div3.head:
Light Artillery!!
Battery secured!!!
bounty Fifty Dollars.!
div3.p: The undersigned having secured a splendid battery of field pieces, have authority to raise a Company of Light Artillery, to be mustered into the service of the Provisional Army of Virginia, for the war Each man will be entitled to a bounty of upon being mustered in. As an opportunity of enlisting in this arm of the service will not hereafter be of frequent occurrence, those wishing to join will make application at once at the rendezvous, northwest corner of Cary and 11th streets, where one or more of the undersigned can always be seen.
Those having substitutes will send them in at once, as the ranks are filling rapidly.
div3.closer:
Stapleton Crutchfield,
William E. Tanner,
Charles E. Wortham. fe 18--ts

div3.p:
--The present condition of our country seems to us to require the services of all who are capable of Bearing arms and in a situation to leave home.
We have therefore obtained from the Secretary of War.
authority to raise a company of Light Artillery.
and call upon our fellow- citizens to come forward and aid us in getting it up.

We want, if possible, to raise a company sufficient to man a battery of six guns, and think this enterprise offers a fine opportunity to all who wish to volunteer, and thus save themselves from a draft in the militia.
Gray uniform, of the Crenshaw Woolen Company Goods, will be furnished free, add the bounty of $50 paid to each man when the company is mustered in.
Rendezvous at the warehouse on the Basin bank, next door to Crenshaw & Co.'s where one of the undersigned may always be found, and recruits maintained free of all expense.
The traveling expenses of recruits from the country to the city will be paid.
div3.closer:
William G. Crenshaw.
James Ellett.
Charles L. Hobson. fe 10--ts Andrew H. Johnston.

div3.head: Attention, young men of Richmond!
div3.p: Having been detailed to recruit for the First Regiment Virginia Volunteers, (now stationed at Centreville,) a bounty of Fifty Dollars, uniform and subsistence, will be given to all able-bodied young men who may enlist in this, the oldest volunteer regiment in the Confederate States.
For further particulars apply at the recruiting station, No. 8, 10th street, between Main and Cary streets.
div3.closer: W. W. Harrison, Lieutenant and Recruiting Officer. P. S.--Two new companies will be received, as there are at present but eight in the regiment. [mh 3--ts] W. W. H.

div3.head: Attention, citizen soldiers!
div3.p:
Fifty or SIXTY
ABLE-Bodied men, Wanted.

The undersigned having had considerable military experience, and recently attached to the Wise Legion as Captain of Artillery.
decides to organize another similar company for immediate service in the Confederate States service.
Each man will be paid Fifty Dollars bounty money when enlisted, and have his uniform furnished.
Now is the time to rally for the defence of our country against the base Yankee invaders.
Headquarters on 10th, between Main and Cary streets. 27--2w*)

div3.head: Recruits Wanted--$50 bounty
div3.p:
--And Uniforms Furnished.--The undersigned, having been duly authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a company of Heavy Artillery, to man the batteries at Yorktown, want a few more men to complete the company.
For further particulars, apply to Sergeant James McDONALD, 12th st., opposite the Enquirer office.
div3.closer:
W. N. Coffin,
Capt. of Artillery.
S. S. Nicholas,
W. P. Woodruff. Those persons who are desirous of enlisting in my company, will also find a Rendezvous on Franklin st., opposite Messrs Dickinson, Hill & Co., where an officer may be found to enroll them. mh 10--6t*

div3.head: Attention!
div3.p:
--The subscribers have authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, to be attached to Major F. J. Boggs's Battalion, to which guns of the most approved kind have been already promised.
As no more flying artillery companies will be received, persons wishing to join this arm of the service will do well to enroll their names at once.
Recent events clearly indicate that Virginia will need the strong arms and brave hearts of all her sons in the impending struggle.
The draft will, with in a few days, compel those to take the field who fall to respond to their country's call in this, her hour of peril.
Fifty dollars bounty paid immediately on being mustered in.
Apply at Bayley & White's office, opposite the Law Building.
div3.closer:
Alexander Q. Holladay,
Lieut. 20th Reg. Va. Vols.
S. Taylor Martin,
lst Company Howitzers.
Wm. F. G. Garnett, Jr.,
Fayette Artillery.
Richard M. Bolling, fe 26--12t* Goochland Troop.

div3.head: Notice
div3.p: --As my term of service will expire on the 21st of April, I wish to raise a volunteer Company, on or before that time, to be mustered into service for the war, or two years. Those who wish to join, can do so by calling on Capt. D. W. Saunders, at the old stand of George Timberlake -- Son, on Brook Avenue.
div3.closer: David B. Jones, fe 22--18t* Company "F." of Richmond.
